column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=3. Computational Analysis
#Text=3.1 .
#Text=Geometric Model

#Text=In the frame of both experimental and theoretical studies , recent technological improvements suggest that in order to enhance the tribological performance concerning the load support and friction properties of the journal bearing , partial texturing must be employed .
#Text=In the present work , textured bearing with a rectangular dimple is of particular interest .
#Text=The reason for using the rectangular-shaped dimple is that this shape is able to achieve the best performance compared to other shapes based on the work of Vilhena et al. .
#Text=Additionally , in practice , it is easier to manufacture it .
#Text=A schematic diagram of smooth ( untextured ) and textured journal bearings is shown in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=.
#Text=The film thickness is approximated by a cosine profile as follows : ( 7 ) where c refers to the radial clearance , ε denotes the eccentricity ratio , and expresses the circumferential angle .
#Text=For the textured bearing studied here , a texture cell is defined by its dimple depth , D , dimple length , W G , and texture cell length , W cell , as shown in the inset of
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=.
#Text=For all following simulations studied here , the texture density , S T ( the ratio of the dimple length , W G , over the texture cell , W cell ) , is assumed to be constant and equal to 0.5 .
#Text=In the present work , more work has been paid to optimizing the texturing parameters with respect to the improvement of the pressure profile and the load support .
#Text=The length of the texturing zone and the dimple depth for three eccentricity ratios were studied for two surface characteristics ( i. e. , with and without slip condition ) .
#Text=With respect to the effect of dimple depth , a dimensionless parameter , D / h min , is introduced , which is the ratio of the dimple depth , D , over the minimal film thickness , h min .
#Text=The surface texturing employed in the present study is a series of dimples on the bearing ( stationary ) surface depending on the length of the texturing zone .

#Text=In terms of the texturing zone , for all following computation , the dimples are introduced from the angular coordinates ( i. e. , circumferential angle ) of , with the reference position measured at the h max as indicated
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=.
#Text=Computations were made by varying the length of the texturing zone , , from 0 – 30 °to 0 – 180 °.
#Text=It should be noted that for all computations , the dimple length , W G , is equal to 5 °.
#Text=In this way , for each interval of the texturing zone of 30 °, there will be six texture cells covering the specified zone .
#Text=A comparative performance analysis between the textured geometry with or without slip and the corresponding smooth configuration was then conducted .
#Text=The parameters studied are the hydrodynamic pressure and the load support .
#Text=The load support , W , per unit length was obtained from the integration of the hydrodynamic pressure acting on the journal .
#Text=3.2 .
#Text=Solution Set Up
#Text=To determine the appropriate mesh density for evaluating the lubricant characteristics of the journal bearing accurately , the meshing analysis needs to be performed .

#Text=In the present study , for the calculation the CFD-based commercial software ANSYS DesignModeler and ANSYS ICEM CFD were employed to produce the computational model and structural mesh , respectively .
#Text=The computational domain is meshed with the uniform quadrilateral grid , as shown in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=.
#Text=The number of mesh points in the longitudinal ( N x ) and transverse ( N z ) direction was varied in order to get mesh independence .

#Text=In addition , more refinement of the mesh system , particularly around the dimple area , was also conducted to capture the presence of the flow recirculation due to the sudden change in texture geometry .
#Text=Consequently , the mesh number used was around 200,000 to 400,000 nodes across the film depending on the texturing zone , dimple depth , and eccentricity ratio .
#Text=In the present work , as reflected in
#Text=Figure 4

#Text=the boundary condition of the computational domain was set as follows : One side of the location of the maximum film thickness , h max , is used as an inlet condition and the other as an outlet .
#Text=The pressure at the inlet ( P in ) and outlet ( P out ) boundaries is taken as the ambient pressure , i. e. , zero pressure .

#Text=The top wall of the lubricant film is modelled as a stationary surface , whereas the bottom surface is modelled as a moving surface assuming no-slip condition and a rotational velocity equal to that of the shaft .
#Text=During the calculation in ANSYS FLUENT® software , the regions of cavitation and the hydrodynamic pressure are computed with the MIXTURE model .
#Text=In the present numerical study , the pressure-based solver was employed .
#Text=The SIMPLEC algorithm was used to treat the pressure – velocity coupling .

#Text=For the momentum equations , the second order upwind discretization scheme was used , whereas the QUICK discretization scheme was employed for the turbulent kinetic energy as well as for the turbulent dissipation rate and the volume fraction equation .
#Text=In the present work , a convergence tolerance of 1 × 10−6 was adopted for all residual terms for more accurate computational results .
